title: RStudio
text:
R and RStudio



Imagine R as a powerful engine



and RStudio as a stylish car

title: RStudio
text: RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) for R and Python from posit.

title: RStudio
text:
It includes a console, syntax-highlighting editor that supports direct code execution, and tools for plotting, history, debugging, and workspace management.
Download RStudio.



Source: https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio/

title: RStudio
text:
R script .R

Write codes in the R script \(\rightarrow\) Console will show the results.


Benefits of writing codes in R script:

You can save it for later use and revision.
You can share with others.
A better track of codes.

title: RStudio
text:
üí° Tips for R script:

Writing readable code because other people might need to use your code.
Writing readable code because you might need to use your code, a few weeks/months/years after you‚Äôve written it.
Put spaces between and around variable names and operators (=+-*/).
Break up long lines of code.
Keeping a consistent style.





Source: Marius Mather also Toma≈æ Ka≈°trun

title: Data  Visualization
text: ‚ÄúThe simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst‚Äôs mind than any other device.‚Äù ‚Äî John Tukey

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Goal
How to visualize data using R package ggplot2.

title: Data  Visualization
text: Source: Tanya Shapiro

title: Data  Visualization
text: ggplot2 Layers

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Import Data

TaskCodeOutput






library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

ggplot(data = penguins)











Figure¬†1

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Map Variables Aesthetics

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species))











Figure¬†2

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Add Geometric Shapes

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar()











Figure¬†3

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Key Components are:


data,
A set of aesthetic mappings between variables in the data and visual properties, and
At least one layer which describes how to render each observation. Layers are usually created with a geom function.

title: Data  Visualization
text:
üß† YOUR TURN

TaskAnswer














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = island)) +
  geom_bar()







‚àí+
05:00

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Common Mistakes

Make sure that every ( is matched with a ) and every " is paired with another ".
Console shows no results but a + sign that means your code is incomplete and R is waiting for you to complete the code.
in ggplot + has to come at the end of the line, not the start

title: Data  Visualization
text:
‚ÄúFill‚Äù Color

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "blue")











Figure¬†4

title: Data  Visualization
text:
‚ÄúFill‚Äù Colors

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar(fill = c("blue", "green", "yellow"))











Figure¬†5

title: Data  Visualization
text:
‚ÄúFill‚Äù & ‚ÄúColor‚Äù Colors

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar(fill = c("blue", "green", "yellow"),
           color = "black")











Figure¬†6

title: Data  Visualization
text:
üß† YOUR TURN

TaskAnswer














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = island)) +
  geom_bar(fill = c("red", "yellow", "darkgreen"),
           color = "black")







‚àí+
05:00

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Know Your Data


glimpse(penguins)

Rows: 344
Columns: 8
$ species           <fct> Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel‚Ä¶
$ island            <fct> Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse‚Ä¶
$ bill_length_mm    <dbl> 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, ‚Ä¶
$ bill_depth_mm     <dbl> 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, ‚Ä¶
$ flipper_length_mm <int> 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186‚Ä¶
$ body_mass_g       <int> 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, ‚Ä¶
$ sex               <fct> male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male‚Ä¶
$ year              <int> 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007‚Ä¶

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Plot A Continuous Variable

TaskCodeOutput






# bill_length_mm is dbl type variable/column

ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram()











Figure¬†7

title: Data  Visualization
text:
üß† YOUR TURN

TaskAnswer














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "darkblue",
                 color = "white")







‚àí+
05:00

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Two Continuous Variables

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point()











Figure¬†8

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Geom Size

TaskCodeOutput














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)











Figure¬†9

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Geom Shape

TaskCodeOutput














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(size = 5,
             shape = 8)











Figure¬†10

title: Data  Visualization
text:
üß† YOUR TURN

TaskAnswer














ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = body_mass_g, y = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_point(size = 2, shape = 23, color = "red", fill = "gold")







‚àí+
05:00

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Plot A Factor & Factor

TaskCodeOutput


Sometimes, we want to differentiate values of a factor/category variable on the basis of another factor/category variable.



ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = island)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill = sex))











Figure¬†11

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Plot A Factor & Continuous

TaskCodeOutput


Sometimes, we want to differentiate values from a continuous variable on the basis of factor/category variables.



ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(fill = sex), color = "black")











Figure¬†12

title: Data  Visualization
text:
A Factor & Two Cont.

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = sex))











Figure¬†13

title: Data  Visualization
text:
A Factor & Two Cont.

TaskCodeOutput






ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species))











Figure¬†14

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Write Labels

TaskCodeOutput



Title of the plot
Subtitle of the plot with more information
Title of the x-axis
Title of the y-axis




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  )











Figure¬†15

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Different Shapes

TaskCodeOutput


Each level of the factor/category can be shown using a different shape of different color.



ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  )











Figure¬†16

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Various Themes

TaskCodeOutput


Source: ggthemes

library(ggthemes)




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_economist()











Figure¬†17

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Various Themes

TaskCodeOutput


Source: ggthemes

library(ggthemes)




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_solarized_2()











Figure¬†18

text:
Various Themes

TaskCodeOutput


Source: ggthemes

library(ggthemes)




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +

    title = "The title of the plot",

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Various Themes

TaskCodeOutput


Source: ggthemes

library(ggthemes)




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(

    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",

title: Data  Visualization
text: Color Palette

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Color Palette

TaskCodeOutput


R package ggthemes have function to use color scheme for colorblindness. Know more



ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_clean() +
  scale_color_colorblind()











Figure¬†21

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Color Palette

TaskCodeOutput



library(RColorBrewer)




ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_clean() +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2")











Figure¬†22

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Color Palette

TaskCodeOutput



library(wesanderson)

names(wes_palettes)

 [1] "BottleRocket1"     "BottleRocket2"     "Rushmore1"        
 [4] "Rushmore"          "Royal1"            "Royal2"           
 [7] "Zissou1"           "Zissou1Continuous" "Darjeeling1"      
[10] "Darjeeling2"       "Chevalier1"        "FantasticFox1"    
[13] "Moonrise1"         "Moonrise2"         "Moonrise3"        
[16] "Cavalcanti1"       "GrandBudapest1"    "GrandBudapest2"   
[19] "IsleofDogs1"       "IsleofDogs2"       "FrenchDispatch"   
[22] "AsteroidCity1"     "AsteroidCity2"     "AsteroidCity3"    





ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_clean() +
  scale_color_manual(values = wes_palette("BottleRocket2", n = 3))











Figure¬†23

title: Data  Visualization
text:
Export Plot

TaskCodeOutput


Export/save plot as pdf, jpg or png file.



ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species, shape = species)) +
  labs(
    title = "The title of the plot",
    subtitle = "The subtitle of the plot",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_clean() +
  scale_color_manual(values = wes_palette("BottleRocket2", n = 3))

ggsave("penguins-plot.pdf")











Figure¬†24

title: R Software
text:
R Programming Language
 





‚ÄúR is a free software environment for statistical computing and graphics.‚Äù



R website link: https://www.r-project.org/

title: R Software
text:
History of R

Intially developed as S language by Bells Labs.
First appeared in August 1993 as R language by:










Ross Ihaka, New Zealand Statistician







Robert Gentleman, Canadian Statistician

title: R Software
text:
Download R from CRAN
https://www.r-project.org/

text:

title: R Software
text:
Workspace image




Don‚Äôt save workspace image.
It helps in ‚Äúfreshly minted R sessions‚Äù.
‚Äúput more trust in your script than in your memory‚Äù.










Source: R Bloggers

Operators

12 + 3 in this code + is an operator.



‚ÄúOperators are used to perform operations on variables and values.‚Äù




Source: w3schools

title: R Software
text:
Arithmetic operators


‚ÄúArithmetic operators are used with numeric values to perform common mathematical operations.‚Äù









Tip


Put spaces between and around operators (= + - * /)

title: R Software
text:
Arithmetic operators




Operator
Name
Example




+
Addition
x + y


-
Subtraction
x - y


*
Multiplication
x * y


/
Division
x / y


^
Exponent
x ^ y





Source: w3schools

text:

Output

text:

title: R Software
text:
R console



Code

3434 + 343453 * 2323 / 534 - 1000


Output
[1] 1496519
 





Important


R follows the BODMAS (bracket, order, division, multiplication, addition and subtraction) rule to solve mathematical equations.

title: R Software
text:
R comparison operators


‚ÄúComparison operators are used to compare two values.‚Äù

title: R Software
text:
R comparison operators




Operator
Name
Example




==
Equal
x == y


!=
Not equal
x != y


>
Greater than
x > y


<
Less than
x < y


>=
Greater than or equal to
x >= y


<=
Less than or equal to
x <= y

text:

Output

text:

Output

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
Data Wrangling

‚Äúdata exploration and data manipulation‚Äù by Jesse Mostipak
‚Äútidying and transforming‚Äù by Hadley & Garrett

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
Transforming Data

‚Äúnarrowing in on observations of interest ‚Ä¶
creating new variables that are functions of existing variables and ‚Ä¶
calculating a set of summary statistics.‚Äù



Source: https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
dplyr Package

‚Äúdplyr is a grammar of data manipulation‚Äù
‚Äúproviding a consistent set of verbs that help you solve the most common data manipulation challenges:‚Äù

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
dplyr Functions:

filter()
select()
mutate()
arrange()
summarise()



Source: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
filter() Function:

Picks cases/observations based on their values.

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
filter() Function

TaskCodeOutput



How to have a data of only Gentoo penguins?





library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(countdown)

penguins |> 
  filter(species == "Gentoo")





# A tibble: 124 √ó 8
   species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Gentoo  Biscoe           46.1          13.2               211        4500
 2 Gentoo  Biscoe           50            16.3               230        5700
 3 Gentoo  Biscoe           48.7          14.1               210        4450
 4 Gentoo  Biscoe           50            15.2               218        5700
 5 Gentoo  Biscoe           47.6          14.5               215        5400
 6 Gentoo  Biscoe           46.5          13.5               210        4550
 7 Gentoo  Biscoe           45.4          14.6               211        4800
 8 Gentoo  Biscoe           46.7          15.3               219        5200
 9 Gentoo  Biscoe           43.3          13.4               209        4400
10 Gentoo  Biscoe           46.8          15.4               215        5150
# ‚Ñπ 114 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>

title: Data  Wrangling
Data  Wrangling
text:
filter() Function

TaskCodeOutput



How to have a data of penguins of bill length more than 43 mm?





penguins |> 
  filter(bill_length_mm > 43)





# A tibble: 188 √ó 8
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           46            21.5               194        4200
 2 Adelie  Dream               44.1          19.7               196        4400
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           45.8          18.9               197        4150

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
üí° Tips for variable selection

Use names() function to see the exact names and the order of the variables.
Use : operator to select the range of variables.


penguins |> 
  select(island : flipper_length_mm)


Use location value of the variable.


penguins |> 
  select(3 : 7)


Use - operator to not to select the range of variables.


# results: hide

penguins |> 
  select(-c(island : flipper_length_mm))

# A tibble: 344 √ó 4
   species body_mass_g sex     year
   <fct>         <int> <fct>  <int>
 1 Adelie         3750 male    2007
 2 Adelie         3800 female  2007
 3 Adelie         3250 female  2007
 4 Adelie           NA <NA>    2007
 5 Adelie         3450 female  2007

 8 Adelie         4675 male    2007
 9 Adelie         3475 <NA>    2007
10 Adelie         4250 <NA>    2007

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
mutate() Function:

Adds new variables that are functions of existing variables.

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
mutate() Function

TaskCodeOutput



How to convert body mass of penguins from grams to kilograms?




penguins |> 
  select(body_mass_g) |> 
  mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000)

   body_mass_g body_mass_kg

 8        4675         4.68

10        4250         4.25

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
summarise() Function:

Reduces multiple values down to a single summary.

title: Data  Wrangling
text:
summarise() Function

TaskCodeOutput



What is the mean bill length of penguins?




penguins |> 
  summarise(mean(bill_length_mm))





# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  `mean(bill_length_mm)`
                   <dbl>
1                     NA

title: Data  Wrangling
Data  Wrangling
Data  Wrangling
text:
summarise() Function

TaskCodeOutput



What is the species wise mean bill length of penguins and total number of penguins in each specie?




penguins |>
  drop_na() |> 
  group_by(species) |> 
  summarise(mean(bill_length_mm),
            n = n())

# n() function to know the number of observations in the current group





# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  species   `mean(bill_length_mm)`     n
  <fct>                      <dbl> <int>
1 Adelie                      38.8   146
2 Chinstrap                   48.8    68
3 Gentoo                      47.6   119

text:
üß† YOUR TURN

  group_by(sex) |> 
  summarise(mean(body_mass_g),
            n = n())





# A tibble: 2 √ó 3
  sex    `mean(body_mass_g)`     n
  <fct>                <dbl> <int>
1 female               3862.   165
2 male                 4546.   168

title: R for Beginners
text:
Star


SARA is a non-profit organization in India. To know more about SARA, kindly vist our website.
This course aims to help the participants to overcome the fear of coding.

It is an annual five days residential training program to learn data science using R programming language.
Students from Underrepresented Communities are Prioritized for Selection.
There is no tuition fee for any participant. The fee of Rs. 6000 (70 USD) includes only the food and accommodation for five days at the SARA Institute, Dr.¬†Ambedkar Bhawan, Sonipat, Haryana - 131001.

Email us at sara.institute.info@gmail.com \(\cdot\) Call us at 925 315 2024.

title: Quarto
text: Quarto

title: Quarto
section: Quarto is the next generation of R Markdown
text:
Quarto is the next generation of R Markdown





  





Read more here From R Markdown to Quarto

title: Quarto
text:
Quarto

‚ÄúAn open-source scientific and technical publishing system‚Äù


Quarto can produce a wide variety of output formats:

 Articles & Reports
 Presentations
 Interactive Docs
 Websites
 Books




Source: Quarto website

title: Quarto
section: Analyze. Share. Reproduce. You have a story to tell with data ‚Äî tell it with Quarto.
text: Analyze. Share. Reproduce. You have a story to tell with data ‚Äî tell it with Quarto.

title: Quarto
section: Process When You Render the Quarto Document
text:
Process When You Render the Quarto Document

Quarto sends the .qmd file to knitr, which executes all of the code chunks and creates a new markdown (.md) document which includes the code and its output. The markdown file generated by knitr is then processed by pandoc, which is responsible for creating the finished file.

title: Quarto
text:
Process When You Render Quarto




Source: Artwork from ‚ÄúHello, Quarto‚Äù keynote by Julia Lowndes and Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel, presented at RStudio::Conf(2022). Illustrated by Allison Horst.

title: Quarto
text: Source editor

title: Code Chunk
text:
Code chunks (or cells or blocks)
Three ways to insert code chunks in the quarto file:

Keyboard shortcuts:

for  Option + Cmd + i.
for  ctrl + alt + i.

 Insert Chunk button in the editor toolbar.
Manually type the chunk delimiters ```{r} and ```.



Source: Jadey Ryan‚Äôs Talk

title: Code Chunk
text:
Code chunks (or cells or blocks)
Two ways to run code chunks:


Use the Run Current Chunk or Run All Chunks Above buttons.
Run the current code chunk with Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + Enter.



Source: Jadey Ryan‚Äôs Talk

title: Code Chunk
text:
Demo  Code  Chunk



 demo_code_chunk.qmd
GIF Source  @dolly_ki_tapri_nagpur

title: Code Chunk
text:
R function

‚ÄúA function, in a programming environment, is a set of instructions.‚Äù
‚ÄúA programmer builds a function to avoid repeating the same task, or reduce complexity.‚Äù

title: Code Chunk
text:
R function

CodeOutput



round(24.3454, 3)


round(argument 1, argument 2)


[1] 24.345

Round function

        to = 30,
        by = 5)

title: Code Chunk

text:
Metacran



Source: Metacran

title: Code Chunk
text:
R packages

Install the R package
Call the R package
Update the R package
Remove the R package
Write the R package



Demo: demo_code_chunk.qmd

title: Code Chunk
text: Install ackages

title: Code Chunk
text: Name of the packages

title: Code Chunk
text: Installed packages

title: Code Chunk
text:
Function to install packages


install.packages("tidyverse")

title: Code Chunk
text:
Function to call package


library(tidyverse)

title: Code Chunk
text:
Using packages

You need to install package only once like:

üìö We buy books once and use them again and again
üí° Fix the bulb once and use it again and again.

title: Code Chunk
text:
Using packages

In every R document you need to call once the package using function library(), for example library(ggplot2).
Once in a while, you need to update the installed packages as well.
If you un-install R or RStudio, you will lose all installed packages.

title: Code Chunk
text: Tools \(\rightarrow\) Package updates

title: Code Chunk
text: Select packages to update

title: Code Chunk
text: Click install updates

title: Code Chunk
text: To remove packages

title: R Objects
text:
R object


Just a name that you can use to call up stored data.








Important


R assignment operators: Assignment operators are used to assign values to variables.
my_var <- 3
my_var # print my_var





Source: Garrett Grolemund

title: R Objects
text:
üí°Guidelines to name R objects:

a name cannot start with a number.
a name cannot use some special symbols, like ^, !, $, @, +, -, /, or *,:.
avoid caps.
avoid space.
use dash (like weight-kg) or underscore (like weight_kg).
if chronology matters then add date (2020-09-05-file-name).

title: R Objects
text:
Create object

CodeOutput



age <- c(23, 25, 16, 40, 34)

age



[1] 23 25 16 40 34

title: R Objects
text:
Create object

CodeOutput

title: R Objects
section: How to create a data object?
text:
How to create a data object?

CodeOutput



example_df <- data.frame(name, income, age, place, weight_kg)

example_df





     name income age place weight_kg
1    Bhim  23000  23    MH        50
2    Rama  25000  25    RJ        52
3    Sara  16000  16    DL        61
4   Phule   4000  40    HR        40
5 Savitri  34000  34    HR        70

title: R Objects
section: Export data as a csv file
text:
Export data as a csv file

CodeOutput



library(readr)

# create a folder in wd & name it "data"
write_csv(example_df, "data/example_df.csv") 



To see the created file, check the ‚Äúdata‚Äù folder in your working directory.
